resources.string: ExpoLIS Mobile App requires an active internet connection to work!
Connection to ExpoLIS database server %1$s failed!
Connection to ExpoLIS MQTT broker %1$s failed!
Checking availability of ExpoLIS route planner…
Please enable the mobile data or turn on the wifi
The ExpoLIS database server may be down for maintenance work.\n\nPlease try again later.
The ExpoLIS MQTT broker may be down for maintenance work.\n\nPlease try again later.
ExpoLIS route planner is offline probably to update its data.\n\nYou can use the app, but the planning feature will not be available for a while.

plurals.name: advice_offline_servers
plurals.item: One of the ExpoLIS servers is offline due to maintenance work and scheduled updates.\nIts corresponding functionality will be disabled.
Some ExpoLIS servers are offline due to maintenance work and scheduled updates.\nTheir corresponding functionalities will be disabled.

resources.string: All ExpoLIS servers are offline due to maintenance work and scheduled updates.\nAll their corresponding functionalities will be disabled.

plurals.name: steps_to_admin
plurals.item: You are at %1$d step to show the admin screen.
You are at %1$d steps to show the admin screen.

resources.string: Enter the ExpoLIS sensor database port number
Enter the ExpoLIS sensor database host name
Enter the ExpoLIS MQTT broker host name
Enter the ExpoLIS MQTT broker port number
Select what sensor data you want to see and which filters you want to apply

This property allows to select what is shown in the map plot if 
• in the case of raw data, more than one sensor reading exists per grid cell; 
• in the case of interpolated data, more than one value exists during the time period (per grid cell). 

Possible options are: the average, maximum or minimum.
Select between viewing the data collected at every location, or to just focus on the data collected near by a bus line.

When data collected at every location is selected, a grid is computed. In this text field the grid cell size can be specified. 

If instead, focus on a bus line is selected, then this field is used to specify how far we go (from the bus line) when considering the data collected by the network sensors. 

Units are meters.
Select which sensor data you want to see, which location you want to analyse and the date range filter to apply

This plot shows the temporal evolution of data collected by the ExpoLIS sensor network. The data is hourly aggregated. \n\nThis property allow to specify how the data is aggregated: compute the average, take the maximum or the minimum.
Drag the red circle to specify the location of the circular region to show on the plot. Zoom in and zoom out to decrease or increase the size of the circular region.

• %1$s of %2$s for each square cell and time period
• square length is %3$.1f meters
• from %4$s to %5$s
• sensor raw data

• %1$s of %2$s for each square cell and time period
• data shown only for bus line %3$s
• only considered data collected at most %4$d meters from the bus line
• from %5$s to %6$s
• sensor raw data

• %1$s of %2$s for each square cell and time period
• square length is %3$d meters
• from %4$s to %5$s
• interpolated data

• %1$s of %2$s
• location %3$s, %4$s
• in a radius of %5$d meters
• from %6$s to %7$s
air quality index is very good
Welcome to the ExpoLIS mobile app. This is the main screen where you can see real time pollution data collected by the sensors in the Carris buses.
In the top right area you can see the time when the last pollution data was recorded. We can also see the bus number whose pollution data is being shown.
Tap the button on the bottom right to select which bus to display real time pollution data.
The plot on the right shows the quantity of particulate matter with sizes 1, 2.5 and 10 microns.
The plot on the left shows the quantity of nitrogen dioxide and carbon monoxide.
The area on the top left shows the temperature and humidity.
The large icon on the top center shows the overall air quality.
Tapping the leftmost button on the bottom goes to the screen where you can edit the properties of the map plot.
Tapping the second button from the left on the bottom goes to the screen where you can edit the properties of the chart plot.
Tapping the middle button on the bottom goes to the planner screen.
In this screen you can select which sensor data to visualise in a map. You can select how to aggregate the data, the time period, and if you want to focus in a particular bus line.
This screen shows a map of sensor data. In the bottom there is a short description of what you selected to plot.
In this screen you can select which sensor data to visualise in a given region. You can select how to aggregate the data and the time period.
This screen shows sensor data in a given location. In the bottom there is a short description of what you selected to plot.
In this screen you can plan a route using different means of transportation and if you want to avoid polluted areas or not.
The first plot (starting from top) gives access to the raw data map. In this plot you can select which pollution data to analyse, how the sensor data is aggregated, date interval, and a resolution.

The pollution is shown as a grid on a map. The size of each grid cell is given by the resolution (units are meters). If more than one sensor reading exists for any given grid cell, then one of the aggregation function is used (average, maximum or minimum).

The second plot gives access to the location chart. In this plot you can select a location on the map: drag the red circle in the map. You can also enlarge or decrease the circle: zoom out or zoom in the map. Any sensor reading within the circle will be aggregated. Again you can select a date interval to filter out sensor readings.
The pollution is shown as chart with time on the horizontal axis, and pollution value on the vertical axis.

The third plot is the interpolated data map. In this plot you can select which pollution data to view and a date interval. \n\n The data collected by the sensor network is used to build a prediction of what the pollution is in a pre-determined region. The prediction is computed using an interpolation method.
This interpolation is presented a grid. If for each grid cell there is more than one interpolated value, we present the average.

The last plot is the line data chart and map. In this plot you can also which pollution data to see, how data is aggregated, a date interval, the line and a distance. \n\n For each line a bus can take, we have a set of locations. For each location we aggregate the sensor data within the specified distance and date interval.

The resulting data is presented in a map and a chart (if applicable). The horizontal axis in the chart data is distance from the line starting position, while the vertical axis contains the pollution data.
